thread.title: Tony Blair's reaction to Chilcot report reveals he not only does God, he thinks he's God
thread.title_full: Tony Blair's reaction to Chilcot report reveals he not only does God, he thinks he's God

title: Tony Blair's reaction to Chilcot report reveals he not only does God, he thinks he's God
text:
Tony Blair's reaction to Chilcot report reveals he not only does God, he thinks he's God 11:30, 9 Jul 2016 Former leader Tony Blair's belief in himself undiminished despite devastating indictment of Iraq War Shares Comments Get daily news by email British Prime Minister Tony Blair returns to Downing Street after appearing before the House of Commons Liaison Committee July 8, 2003 in London 
Tony Blair not only does God, it seems he is God. 
Or so he thinks, judging by his reaction to the Chilcot report into the Iraq war. 
The intelligence was flawed, the legal case for war was ‘not satisfactory’, the military was unprepared and, most worryingly for a man with a hotline to heaven, nobody saw what was coming in regard to an extremist and terrorist backlash. 
Yet despite the countless dead, including 179 British service personnel and the global chaos that has ensued as direct result of the action, Blair still believes he was right as he helped make the world a safer place and would do it all again if given the chance. 
Then let’s thank, well, God, that he will never be in a position - ie prime minister - to do it again, despite the dewy eyed adulation of those who would have Blair or a Blairite Labour leader to replace Jeremy Corbyn because winning is everything. Gareth Fuller/PA Wire A woman wearing a t-shirt in tribute to Senior Aircraftsman Christopher Dunsmore, who died in Iraq, carries the Iraq Inquiry Report as she leaves the Queen Elizabeth II Conference Centre, London, after the publication of the Chilcot inquiry into the Iraq War 
Now it could be argued that Chilcot might not only have destroyed any shred of reputation Blair had left, he might help save the position of Corbyn. 
For, post Chilcot, Labour MPs might find themselves re-thinking what kind of a leader they want. 
One like Blair with the despotic arrogance to not even consult his Cabinet while disregarding the view of millions who took part in peace rallies around the globe when making the most important post World War II decision on foreign policy matters. 
Compared to it, voting for Brexit was like deciding what curtains to hang in number 10. 
Or one like Corbyn who, although far from perfect, might actually be interested in other people’s views on a matter of such great importance and view war as a last, not a first, resort. 
Some - actually, probably all - Labour MPs might guffaw and remind us that their present leader was well known for going his own way and voting against the party line. Like he did when he voted against the Iraq war - the deceitful devil. 
It was also interesting how his potential rivals - Angela Eagle and Tom Watson - and the man who set the ball rolling, Hilary Benn, voted FOR it. Ian Austin, Labour MP for Dudley North, and former press secretary to Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown 
The post Chilcot debate was debased by Labour MP Ian Austin telling Corbyn to ‘sit down and shut up’ and calling him a ‘disgrace’ as his leader dissected Blair’s Iraq war role. I wonder if the families of those who lost loved ones in the conflict agreed with Austin, or even if he cared what he thought, so keen is he to ‘Get Corbyn’. 
Still, Austin is easily ignored. What won’t be so easily ignored is the Chilcot report. Before its publication, because it took seven years, there were fears of a whitewash. It proved well worth the wait.
